questiontext.text: Consider a nucleus that undergoes \(\beta^-\) decay followed by \(\gamma\) emission from an excited state of the daughter nucleus. Which statement about the net changes in \((A,Z)\) and the physical origin of the emitted radiations is most accurate?

generalfeedback.text: In \(\beta^-\) decay, a neutron converts to a proton, so \(A\) stays constant while \(Z\) increases by 1. \(\gamma\) emission is a nuclear de-excitation process (photon emission) that does not change either \(A\) or \(Z\), but reduces the nuclear energy. A decrease by 4 in \(A\) and 2 in \(Z\) describes alpha decay, not \(\beta^-\) decay. A claim that \(\gamma\) emission causes nucleon conversion confuses it with beta processes, while describing \(\gamma\) as an electronic transition confuses nuclear radiation with atomic spectroscopy.

answer.text: \(A\) decreases by 4 and \(Z\) decreases by 2; \(\gamma\) emission occurs due to electron transitions
\(A\) remains the same and \(Z\) increases by 1; \(\gamma\) emission corresponds to de-excitation of the nucleus without changing \((A,Z)\)
\(A\) remains the same and \(Z\) decreases by 1; \(\gamma\) emission converts a neutron into a proton
\(A\) increases by 1 and \(Z\) remains the same; \(\gamma\) emission is the emission of a helium nucleus

questiontext.text: A student claims: “A nuclear reaction is exothermic whenever products have larger total mass than reactants, because extra mass becomes energy.” Which correction best aligns with the Q-value concept and mass–energy relation?

generalfeedback.text: The Q-value represents the energy released (positive) or absorbed (negative) in a nuclear reaction and is determined by the mass difference between reactants and products. If the products have lower total mass than reactants, the mass defect corresponds to released energy via \(Q=(m_\text{reactants}-m_\text{products})c^2\). Saying “extra mass becomes energy” reverses the direction: energy release corresponds to a decrease in mass, not an increase. Half-life governs spontaneous decay kinetics and is not the criterion for whether an arbitrary nuclear reaction is exothermic.

answer.text: Exothermic reactions require product mass greater than reactant mass; Q-value is negative
Exothermic reactions require product mass less than reactant mass; Q-value is positive and equals \((m_\text{reactants}-m_\text{products})c^2\)
Exothermicity cannot be inferred from masses because Q-value depends only on half-life
Exothermic reactions require product mass equal to reactant mass; Q-value is always zero

questiontext.text: Two nuclei are compared for stability reasoning: one has a notably higher binding energy per nucleon than the other. Which inference is most defensible about their relative nuclear stability and tendency toward radioactivity?

generalfeedback.text: Binding energy reflects how strongly nucleons are held together, so higher binding energy per nucleon generally indicates greater nuclear stability. Interpreting higher binding energy as “more stored energy that must be released” is a misconception; stronger binding typically means the nucleus is less eager to rearrange spontaneously. Detector choice affects measurement, not the intrinsic stability of the nucleus. Decay mode selection (alpha, beta, gamma) depends on specific stability factors and conservation requirements, so no single decay type is guaranteed solely from “higher binding energy per nucleon.”

answer.text: The nucleus with higher binding energy per nucleon is generally more stable against spontaneous change
The nucleus with higher binding energy per nucleon is necessarily more radioactive because it “contains more energy”
Binding energy per nucleon is unrelated to stability; only detector choice determines apparent stability
Higher binding energy per nucleon guarantees the nucleus must undergo beta decay

questiontext.text: In a fission reactor discussion, which statement best links criticality, the multiplication factor \(k\), and reactor safety considerations without mixing them up with radioactive half-life concepts?

generalfeedback.text: The multiplication factor \(k\) governs whether the neutron population decreases (\(k<1\)), stays steady (\(k=1\)), or increases (\(k>1\)), which directly defines subcritical, critical, and supercritical states. Reactor control and safety revolve around managing neutron multiplication and chain reactions, not changing the half-life of the fuel. Q-value describes energy release per reaction, but sustaining a chain reaction depends on neutron production, losses, and the overall neutron economy captured qualitatively by \(k\).

answer.text: Criticality is achieved when half-life of the fuel equals the neutron generation time
A reactor is critical when \(k=1\); safety systems aim to keep the system from becoming supercritical (\(k>1\)) in an uncontrolled manner
A reactor is subcritical when \(k>1\); it then requires shielding to reduce half-life
Criticality is determined only by the Q-value and does not involve neutron economy

questiontext.text: Fusion between light nuclei in stars occurs at energies lower than the classical Coulomb barrier would suggest. Which explanation best integrates the Coulomb barrier idea with the mechanism enabling fusion?

generalfeedback.text: The Coulomb barrier is the electrostatic repulsion between positively charged nuclei that must be overcome or penetrated for fusion to occur. Quantum tunneling provides a finite probability for nuclei to pass through the barrier even when classical kinetic energy is insufficient, enabling fusion under stellar conditions. The barrier is repulsive (not attractive) at relevant separations until the strong nuclear force dominates at very short range, so long-distance attraction is incorrect. Electrons can screen repulsion partially but do not remove it completely, and gamma emission does not “increase charge to reduce repulsion” (it does not change \(Z\)). (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/d13e1942-f9f7-4189-9aa9-1f84857a7358/inorganic_unit_08.txt)

answer.text: Fusion proceeds because the Coulomb barrier becomes attractive at long distances
Fusion proceeds because electrons eliminate the Coulomb repulsion completely in stellar cores
Fusion proceeds because quantum tunneling allows nuclei to penetrate the Coulomb barrier with nonzero probability
Fusion proceeds because gamma emission increases the charge of nuclei, reducing repulsion

questiontext.text: Radioactivity is best described as:

generalfeedback.text: Radioactivity is a nuclear phenomenon in which an unstable nucleus transforms and emits radiation (such as alpha, beta, or gamma). Emission of visible light from excited atoms is an electronic transition, not a nuclear change. Chemical decomposition concerns rearrangement of electrons in bonds, not changes in the nucleus. Heating can cause thermionic emission or ionization, but that is not radioactivity.

answer.text: Spontaneous emission of radiation from unstable nuclei
Emission of visible light from excited atoms only
Chemical decomposition of unstable molecules into radicals
Loss of electrons from atoms due to heating

questiontext.text: In terms of nucleon numbers, alpha decay of a nuclide \(\,^{A}_{Z}X\,\) produces a daughter nuclide with:

generalfeedback.text: An alpha particle is a \(\,^{4}_{2}\mathrm{He}\,\) nucleus, so emission reduces the parent mass number by 4 and atomic number by 2. A reduction by 2 in mass number corresponds to losing two nucleons only, which is not an alpha particle. Reducing atomic number by 4 would imply loss of four protons, which is not the alpha process. Keeping mass number unchanged would contradict emission of a massive particle.

answer.text: Mass number \(A-2\) and atomic number \(Z-2\)
Mass number \(A-4\) and atomic number \(Z-2\)
Mass number \(A-4\) and atomic number \(Z-4\)
Mass number \(A\) and atomic number \(Z-2\)

questiontext.text: Which statement correctly distinguishes gamma emission from alpha and beta decay?

generalfeedback.text: Gamma rays are high-energy photons emitted when an excited nucleus de-excites, so nucleon counts (A and Z) remain unchanged while nuclear energy decreases. Changing mass number requires emission of massive particles (like alpha) or nucleon loss. Changing atomic number occurs in beta processes or electron capture, not in pure gamma emission. Converting a proton into a neutron is characteristic of positron emission or electron capture, not gamma emission.

answer.text: Gamma emission changes the mass number of the nucleus.
Gamma emission changes the atomic number of the nucleus.
Gamma emission changes neither mass number nor atomic number, but lowers nuclear energy.
Gamma emission converts a proton into a neutron.

questiontext.text: The mass defect of a nucleus is defined as:

generalfeedback.text: Mass defect is the “missing mass” when separated protons and neutrons bind to form a nucleus, reflecting conversion of mass into binding energy. Mass number is a count, not a mass, so comparing it directly to measured mass is not the definition. Neutron–proton difference relates to stability trends but is not mass defect. Radii differences are geometric properties and do not define mass defect.

answer.text: Difference between the measured atomic mass and the mass number
Difference between the total mass of separated nucleons and the actual nuclear mass
Difference between the number of neutrons and the number of protons
Difference between the nucleus radius and atomic radius

questiontext.text: Binding energy is most directly related to mass defect by:

generalfeedback.text: Nuclear binding energy corresponds to the energy equivalent of mass defect via Einstein’s mass–energy equivalence, \(E=\Delta m c^2\). Dividing by \(c^2\) would convert energy into mass, not mass into energy. Inverting \(\Delta m\) has no physical basis here. Multiplying by \(c\) gives incorrect units and does not represent mass–energy equivalence.

answer.text: \(E = \Delta m\,c^2\)
\(E = \Delta m/c^2\)
\(E = c^2/\Delta m\)
\(E = \Delta m\,c\)

questiontext.text: In \(\beta^-\) decay, the nuclear change responsible for electron emission is best represented as:

generalfeedback.text: In \(\beta^-\) decay, a neutron converts into a proton with emission of an electron (and an antineutrino, often omitted in basic notation). Converting a proton into a neutron with electron emission is not the \(\beta^-\) process. Positron emission corresponds to \(\beta^+\) decay, not \(\beta^-\). Electron capture corresponds to a proton capturing an inner electron to form a neutron, which is a different mode.

answer.text: \(\mathrm{p} \rightarrow \mathrm{n} + e^- \)
\(\mathrm{n} \rightarrow \mathrm{p} + e^- \)
\(\mathrm{n} \rightarrow \mathrm{p} + e^+ \)
\(\mathrm{p} + e^- \rightarrow \mathrm{n}\)

questiontext.text: A Geiger–Müller (GM) counter primarily detects radiation by measuring:

generalfeedback.text: A GM counter is a gas-filled ionization detector; radiation creates ion pairs and triggers an avalanche, producing detectable pulses. Heating is not the operating principle of GM tubes. Photographic film detection is a separate dosimetry/recording method, not GM counting. Radiation can induce chemical changes, but GM counters do not measure chemical kinetics.

answer.text: Increase in temperature of the gas due to radiation heating
Ionization produced in a gas-filled tube leading to an electrical pulse
Formation of photographic images on a film inside the detector
Chemical reaction rate changes caused by radiation

questiontext.text: For a radioactive sample, after exactly two half-lives, the fraction of nuclei remaining is:

generalfeedback.text: Each half-life reduces the number of undecayed nuclei by a factor of 2, so after two half-lives the remaining fraction is \((1/2)^2 = 1/4\). A remaining fraction of \(1/2\) corresponds to only one half-life. A fraction \(1/3\) does not arise from repeated halving. A fraction \(1/8\) corresponds to three half-lives.

questiontext.text: The Q-value of a nuclear reaction is best interpreted as:

generalfeedback.text: The Q-value is the net energy change of a nuclear process, determined by mass–energy differences between reactants and products. Neutron yield is a different quantity and depends on the specific reaction channel. Decay rate constants describe spontaneous decay kinetics, not reaction energetics. Detector registration probability depends on efficiency and geometry, not on the reaction Q-value.

answer.text: The total number of neutrons produced in the reaction
The energy released (positive) or absorbed (negative) by the reaction
The rate constant of radioactive decay
The probability that a detector will register a count

questiontext.text: Which statement correctly identifies a key distinction between nuclear fission and nuclear fusion?

generalfeedback.text: Fission is the splitting of a heavy nucleus into lighter fragments, while fusion is the combination of light nuclei to form a heavier nucleus. Reversing these descriptions swaps the processes incorrectly. Both are nuclear processes, not chemical electron-transfer reactions. Many fission and fusion reactions release energy, so they are not always endothermic. (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/d13e1942-f9f7-4189-9aa9-1f84857a7358/inorganic_unit_08.txt)

answer.text: Fission combines light nuclei; fusion splits heavy nuclei.
Fission splits heavy nuclei; fusion combines light nuclei.
Both processes are chemical reactions involving electron transfer.
Both processes always require absorption of energy (endothermic).

questiontext.text: A radioactive nuclide has half-life 10 days. If the initial number of nuclei is \(N_0\), what fraction remains undecayed after 30 days?

generalfeedback.text: After each half-life, the number of undecayed nuclei halves, so after \(n\) half-lives the remaining fraction is \((1/2)^n\). Here, 30 days corresponds to \(30/10 = 3\) half-lives, so remaining fraction is \((1/2)^3 = 1/8\). Values like \(1/4\) and \(1/2\) correspond to only 2 and 1 half-lives respectively, while \(1/16\) corresponds to 4 half-lives.

questiontext.text: A sample shows an activity of 1600 disintegrations per second at \(t=0\). The half-life is 5 s. What is the activity after 15 s (ignore detector effects)?

generalfeedback.text: Activity is proportional to the number of undecayed nuclei, so it halves every half-life just like \(N\). 15 s corresponds to \(15/5 = 3\) half-lives, so \(A = 1600 \times (1/2)^3 = 200\) dps. 800 dps and 400 dps correspond to 1 and 2 half-lives respectively. 100 dps would correspond to 4 half-lives (20 s), not 15 s.

answer.text: 800 dps
400 dps
200 dps
100 dps

questiontext.text: A nuclide has decay constant \(\lambda = 0.0693\ \text{day}^{-1}\). Its half-life is closest to:

generalfeedback.text: The relation between half-life and decay constant is \(t_{1/2} = \ln 2 / \lambda\). Since \(\ln 2 \approx 0.693\), \(t_{1/2} \approx 0.693/0.0693 = 10\) days. 5 days would require \(\lambda\) roughly twice as large. 15–20 days would require a smaller \(\lambda\) than given.

answer.text: 5 days
10 days
15 days
20 days

questiontext.text: A detector records 240 counts in 2 minutes from a source. The background is 30 counts in 2 minutes. If the detector efficiency is 20%, the source activity (disintegrations per second) is:

generalfeedback.text: First subtract background to get net source counts: \(240-30=210\) counts in 2 minutes. Convert to net count rate: \(210/120 = 1.75\ \text{counts s}^{-1}\). Efficiency \(\varepsilon = 0.20\) means \(\text{count rate} = \varepsilon \times \text{activity}\), so \(\text{activity} = \frac{1.75}{0.20} = 8.75\ \text{dps}\). 0.875 dps results from multiplying by efficiency instead of dividing (a common efficiency misconception). 1.75 dps results from assuming 100% efficiency (forgetting the efficiency correction). 10.5 dps results from a time-conversion/rounding error (using an incorrect seconds conversion or inconsistent rate basis).

answer.text: 1.75 dps
8.75 dps
10.5 dps

questiontext.text: A nucleus undergoes \(\beta^-\) decay. Which change occurs in \((A,Z)\) of the nucleus?

generalfeedback.text: In \(\beta^-\) decay, a neutron converts to a proton, so mass number \(A\) stays the same while atomic number \(Z\) increases by 1. A decrease of \(A\) by 4 and \(Z\) by 2 corresponds to alpha decay. A decrease in \(Z\) by 1 (with same \(A\)) corresponds to \(\beta^+\) decay or electron capture. Increasing \(A\) by 1 is not a result of beta decay.

answer.text: \(A\) decreases by 4, \(Z\) decreases by 2
\(A\) unchanged, \(Z\) increases by 1
\(A\) unchanged, \(Z\) decreases by 1
\(A\) increases by 1, \(Z\) unchanged

questiontext.text: A nuclear reaction has reactant mass (total) 236.0526 u and product mass (total) 236.0504 u. Using \(1\ \text{u} = 931.5\ \text{MeV}\), the Q-value (in MeV) is closest to:

generalfeedback.text: Mass defect \(\Delta m = 236.0526 - 236.0504 = 0.0022\ \text{u}\). Q-value \(Q = \Delta m \times 931.5 \approx 0.0022 \times 931.5 \approx 2.05\ \text{MeV}\), which matches 2.0 MeV, not 20 MeV. The common misconception is misplacing the decimal (treating 0.0022 as 0.022). Very small Q-values like 0.2 MeV would require \(\Delta m\) about 10 times smaller, and 200 MeV would require \(\Delta m\) about 0.2 u.

answer.text: 0.2 MeV
2.0 MeV
20 MeV
200 MeV

questiontext.text: The mean lifetime \(\tau\) of a radioactive nuclide is 2 hours. Its half-life is closest to:

generalfeedback.text: Mean lifetime \(\tau = 1/\lambda\) and half-life \(t_{1/2} = (\ln 2)/\lambda\). Eliminating \(\lambda\) gives \(t_{1/2} = \tau \ln 2 \approx 2 \times 0.693 = 1.386\) h. 2.00 h incorrectly assumes half-life equals mean life. 0.69 h corresponds to \(\tau = 1\) h. 2.89 h corresponds to multiplying by \(1/\ln 2\), which is the inverse relation.

questiontext.text: A radioactive sample follows \(N=N_0 e^{-\lambda t}\). If after 4 hours the sample retains 25% of its original nuclei, the half-life is:

generalfeedback.text: Retaining 25% means \(N/N_0 = 1/4 = (1/2)^2\), i.e., two half-lives have passed. If 2 half-lives correspond to 4 hours, then one half-life is 2 hours. 1 hour would imply four half-lives in 4 hours, leaving \(1/16\). 4 hours would imply one half-life, leaving \(1/2\). 8 hours would imply half-life longer than the observation time, inconsistent with reaching 25%.

answer.text: 1 hour
2 hours
4 hours
8 hours

questiontext.text: A fission chain reaction has multiplication factor \(k=1.05\). Which statement best describes the reactor state?

generalfeedback.text: The multiplication factor \(k\) indicates whether each generation produces more, equal, or fewer neutrons than the previous generation. If \(k>1\), the chain reaction is supercritical and the neutron population grows. If \(k=1\), it is critical and steady. If \(k<1\), it is subcritical and dies out. Fuel half-life is unrelated to the prompt neutron multiplication condition.

answer.text: Subcritical: neutron population decreases with time
Critical: neutron population remains steady
Supercritical: neutron population increases with time
Cannot be inferred without knowing the half-life of the fuel

questiontext.text: For a given nuclide, which instrument primarily relies on gas ionization to produce measurable electrical pulses, making it suitable for count-rate measurements?

generalfeedback.text: A Geiger–Müller counter is a gas-filled ionization detector that produces pulses from ionization avalanches, enabling direct counting. Film badges record cumulative exposure rather than producing real-time electronic pulses. Chemical dosimeters rely on radiation-induced chemical changes and are not pulse-counting instruments. A cloud chamber visualizes tracks by condensation and is not primarily an electronic pulse detector in the usual measurement sense. If Q4 should be corrected and re-issued with consistent options, say so and it will be regenerated with a clean single correct choice. (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/d13e1942-f9f7-4189-9aa9-1f84857a7358/inorganic_unit_08.txt)

answer.text: Geiger–Müller counter
Photographic film badge
Chemical dosimeter solution
Cloud chamber only (without electrodes)
